Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The 9th International Workshop on Bio-Design Automation (IWBDA) 2017 will bring together researchers from electronic design automation (the practice of using computer software to build complex electronics) and synthetic biology (the forward design of novel biological systems using engineering principles). The goal of IWBDA is to make biology more easily, robustly, reliably, and predictably engineered and therefore, tackle challenges in biology and medicine, leading to advances in disease diagnosis, treatment and prevention. IWBDA 2017 will take place in Pittsburgh PA. Participants from more than 30 different US and international universities are expected to attend this workshop. IWBDA will capture and make public the slides, posters, and abstracts from the session. In addition, a user survey will be created to learn more about how workshops like this can better serve the community. Finally, there will be numerous undergraduate, graduate and post graduate student researchers in attendance. IWBDA encourages and supports woman and underrepresented minority student participation and has a diverse technical program and executive committees.


This workshop will provide a venue for between twelve and fifteen technical talks over two days. These talks are chosen from two page extended abstracts which are later archived. In addition, there will be two invited lectures, ten to twenty posters, multiple group discussion sessions, and a featured student programming competition (BDAthlon). Technical topics will be diverse and include areas such as: Parts and Standardization, Biological Circuit Simulators, Biological Circuit Design, CAD Tools for Synthetic Biology and Gene Network Reconstruction.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2017 International Workshop on Bio-Design Automation (IWBDA) was held August 8th - 11th 2017 at The University of Pittsburgh.  IWBDA brought together researchers from electronic design automation (the practice of using computer software to build complex electronics) and synthetic biology (the forward design of novel biological systems using engineering principles).  The goal of IWBDA is to make biology more easily, robustly, reliably, and predictably engineered and therefore, tackle challenges in biology and medicine, leading to advances in disease diagnosis, treatment and prevention.  There were a total of more than 100 participants from major research universities and industry. Approximately half of the participants were graduate student researchers.  In addition to NSF sponsorship, industrial participation was also a key contributor to the quality of the workshop and related discussions. Industrial sponsors included: Twist Bioscience, Raytheon BBN Technologies, SynBiCITE, DSM, ACS Synthetic Biology, Minres Technologies, Amyris, Teselagen Biotechnology, Agilent, and Cytoscape. 


This workshop had six technical talk sessions: Experiment-Machine Interfaces, Design Automation, Genetic Design Spaces, Modeling, Standards and Domain Specific Languages, and Machine Learning. In these sessions there were a total of 18, 20 minute talks selected from peer-reviewed, extended abstracts. These abstracts are archived on the website program. In addition, there were two keynote speakers. They were Dr. Caroline Ajo-Franklin from Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory (“Engineering Microorganisms that Create and Communicate with Materials") and Prof. James Faeder from the University of Pittsburgh (“Rule-based modeling of cellular processes”).  There were 14 posters presented, a programming contest ("BDAthlon"), and a whole group discussion sessions. ACS Synthetic Biology used submissions as part of a “special issue” highlighting the technical contributions of the workshop.


For more information please see: http://www.iwbdaconf.org/2017/


Last Modified: 08/08/2018
Modified by: Douglas Densmore
